content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students is provided with a tall, liquid-filled container with a very small hole near the bottom of one side. The hole is plugged with a removable stopper. The cylinder is filled with liquid and rests on a table. The students have access to the cylinder with liquid, books which can be used to raise the height of the container, and a meter stick. They are asked to create a graph using measured quantities in order to determine the initial speed of the liquid exiting the hole when the stopper is removed.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to find the speed of the liquid coming from the container. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students is provided with a tall, liquid-filled container with a very small hole near the bottom of one side. The hole is plugged with a removable stopper. The cylinder is filled with liquid and rests on a table. The students have access to the cylinder with liquid, books which can be used to raise the height of the container, and a meter stick. They are asked to create a graph using measured quantities in order to determine the initial speed of the liquid exiting the hole when the stopper is removed.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to find the speed of the liquid coming from the container. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be graphed, and how that graph would be analyzed, to determine the speed of the liquid as it leaves the hole in the container.

In a different experiment, the students use the same container filled with a liquid of unknown density. The students use a pressure sensor to measure the gauge pressure of the liquid at the location of the hole. They then remove the stopper and collect the data to determine the speed at which the liquid exits the container. They repeat the experiment with different amounts of liquid in the container. Their collected data are shown in the table below.
Gauge Pressure <math alttext="P sub gauge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>gauge</mtext></msub></math> <math alttext="in kilopascals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>kPa</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> <math alttext="in meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mpadded><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>m/s</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow></mpadded></mstyle></math><math alttext="7.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>7.8</mtext></math><math alttext="4.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4.4</mtext></math><math alttext="6.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>6.2</mtext></math><math alttext="4.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4.0</mtext></math><math alttext="4.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>4.8</mtext></math><math alttext="3.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>3.4</mtext></math><math alttext="3.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>3.0</mtext></math><math alttext="2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>2.8</mtext></math><math alttext="0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0.8</mtext></math><math alttext="1.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>1.4</mtext></math>
The students correctly determine that the relationship between the gauge pressure and the speed of the liquid leaving the hole is given by <math alttext="P sub gauge equals, one half times rho v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>gauge</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>ρ</mi><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. The students create a graph with <math alttext="P sub gauge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>gauge</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> plotted on the vertical axis.
(c)

i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the horizontal axis to yield a linear graph whose slope can be used to calculate an experimental value for the density <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>ρ</mi></mstyle></math> of the liquid. You may use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities (including units) that are not already in the table.

Vertical Axis:____ <math alttext="P sub gauge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>gauge</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> ____          Horizontal Axis:__________

ii. On the grid shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)i that can be used to determine <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math>. Scale the graph as appropriate. Clearly label the horizontal axis, including units.
iii. Draw a best – fit straight line for the data.

(d) Calculate an experimental value for the density <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math>, of the liquid using the best-fit line that you drew in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.
